Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX To whom it may concern : I am responding to the letter you sent dated about a debt you are trying to collect. Be advised this is not a refusal to pay, but a notice sent pursuant to the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act 15 USC 1692 ( g ). This claim is being disputed and a debt validation is requested. I also have reason to believe that you are in violation of 15 USC 1692e. False or misleading representations as defined ( 3 ) The false representation or implication that any individual is an attorney or that any communication is from an attorney. This is NOT a request for verification or proof of my mailing address, but a request for VALIDATION made pursuant to the abovenamed Title and Section. The account listed below : XXXX Per Code US Code 1681 e ( b ) Whenever a consumer reporting agency prepares a consumer report it shall follow reasonable procedures to assure maximum possible accuracy of the information concerning the individual about whom the report relates. PLEASE DELETE OFF MY REPORT I respectfully request your offices provide me with competent evidence that I have any legal obligation to pay you. You contacted me by mail, on and identified the alleged debt as being the original creditor. Please supply the information below so that I can be fully informed : Why you think I owe the debt and to whom I owe it, including : The name and address of the creditor to whom the debt is currently owed, the account number used by that creditor, and the amount owed. 
If this debt started with a different creditor, provide the name and address of the original creditor, the account number used by that creditor, and the amount owed to that creditor at the time it was transferred. When you identify the original creditor, please provide any other name by which I might know them, if that is different from the official name. In addition, tell me when the current creditor obtained the debt and who the current creditor obtained it from. 
Provide verification and documentation that there is a valid basis for claiming that I am required to pay the debt to the current creditor. For example, can you provide a copy of the written agreement that created my original requirement to pay? 
If you are asking that I pay a debt that somebody else is or was required to pay, identify that person. Provide verification and documentation about why this is a debt that I am required to pay. The amount and age of the debt, including : A copy of the last billing statement sent to me by the original creditor. 
State the amount of the debt when you obtained it, and when that was. 
If there have been any additional interest, fees or charges added since the last billing statement from the original creditor, provide an itemization showing the dates and amount of each added amount. In addition, explain how the added interest, fees or other charges are expressly authorized by the agreement creating the debt or are permitted by law. 
If there have been any payments or other reductions since the last billing statement from the original creditor, provide an itemization showing the dates and amount of each of them If there have been any other changes or adjustments since the last billing statement from the original creditor, please provide full verification and documentation of the amount you are trying to collect. Explain how that amount was calculated. In addition, explain how the other changes or adjustments are expressly authorized by the agreement creating the debt or permitted by law. 
Tell me when the creditor claims this debt became due and when it became delinquent. 
Identify the date of the last payment made on this account. 
Have you made a determination that this debt is within the statute of limitations applicable to it? Tell me when you think the statute of limitations expires for this debt, and how you determined that. Details about your authority to collect this debt. 
I would like more information about your firm before I discuss the debt with you. Does your firm have a debt collection license from my state? If not, say why not. If so, provide the date of the license, the name on the license, the license number, and the name, address and telephone number of the state agency issuing the license. 
If you are contacting me from a place outside my state, does your firm have a debt collection license from that place? If so, provide the date of the license, the name on the license, the license number, and the name, address and telephone number of the state agency issuing the license. 
I have asked for this information because I have some questions. I need to hear from you to make an informed decision about your claim that I owe this money. I am open to communicating with you for this purpose. In order to make sure that I am not put at any disadvantage, in the meantime please treat this debt as being in dispute and under discussion between us. 
PROVIDE ME WITH THE FOLLOWING AS WELL : 1. FULL DISCLOSURE I WAS NOT TOLD THAT YOU WERE ACTUALLY CREATING THE CREDIT WITH MY WET INK SIGNATURE 2. EQUAL CONSIDERATION THEY BROUGHT NOTHING OF VALUE TO THE TABLE AND HAS NOTHING TO LOSE 3. LAWFUL TERMS AND CONDITIONS BECAUSE YOURS WERE BASED ON FRAUD 4. THE WET INK SIGNATURES OF BOTH PARTIES I AM WRITING TO INFORM YOU THAT IM NOT IN DISPUTE WITH ANYTHING BUT I DEMAND THE FOLLOWING LISTED ABOVE BE PROVIDED IN ORDER FOR ME TO BE ABLE TO MAKE PAYMENT. 
PLEASE RESPOND BACK WITHIN 10 DAYS OF THIS CERTIFIED LETTER. 
IF YOU DO NOT RESPOND I WILL CONSIDER THE DEBT TO BE FULLY DISCHARGED AND I WILL NEED IT IN WRITING SINCE YOU DID NOT RESPOND BY THE STATED ABOVE TERMS TO PROVIDE THE NECCESSARY EVIDENCE OF A LAWFUL DEBT WITHIN THE REASONABLE PERIOD OF TIME PROVIDE, I WILL CONSIDER THE DEBT IS FULLY DISCHARDED. 
WITHOUT PREJUDICE XXXX XXXX XXXX

Under 15 USC 1681i ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) subject to subsection ( f ) and except as provided in subsection ( g ), If the completeness or accuracy of any item of information contained in a consumer 's file at a consumer reporting agency is disputed by the consumer and the consumer notifies the agency directly or indirectly through a reseller, of such dispute, the agency shall, free of charge, conduct a reasonable reinvestigation to determine whether the disputed information is inaccurate and record the current status of the disputed information, or delete the item from the file in accordance with paragraph ( 5 ), before the end of the 30-day period beginning on the date on which the agency receives the notice of the dispute from the consumer or reseller.

Sub-issue: Reporting company used your report improperly
Consumer complaint narrative:
In accordance with the Fair Credit Reporting act. The List of accounts below has violated my federally protected consumer rights to privacy and confidentiality under 15 USC 1681. 
XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX and XXXX XXXX has violated my rights 15 U.S.C 1681 section 602 A. States I have the right to privacy.

15 U.S.C 1681 Section 604 A Section 2 : It also states a consumer reporting agency can not furnish a account without my written instructions 15 U.S.C 1681c. ( a ) ( 5 ) Section States : no consumer reporting agency may make any consumer report containing any of the following items of information Any other adverse item of information, other than records of convictions of crimes which antedates the report by more than seven years.

15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( A ) ( 1 ) A person shall not furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate.

Consumer complaint narrative:
This letter serves as a formal notice under the Fair Debt Collection Practices Act ( FDCPA ) and specifically 15 U.S.C. 1692c ( c ), requiring you to cease all communication with me regarding the alleged debt associated with the account. In the amount of {$1100.00} As stated under 15 U.S.C. 1692c ( c ), once you receive this written notice, you are legally obligated to stop all communication with me concerning this matter, except to : Notify me that your further collection efforts have been terminated ; Inform me of any specified remedies that may be invoked by you or the original creditor ; or Notify me of your intent to invoke a specified remedy.

Furthermore, I am formally notifying you that I consider any updates to my credit report as a form of indirect communication regarding this account. If you continue to report, update, or otherwise communicate through credit reporting agencies, I will consider this a violation of the FDCPA. 

If this account is in dispute, I reserve the right to validate or challenge its accuracy, and I expect all collection activity to be suspended as per applicable laws. Any further communication with me outside the outlined exceptions or continued reporting on my credit report will result in formal complaints filed with the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ), the Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ), and legal action if necessary. 

Please confirm in writing within 14 days of receiving this letter that you have complied with my request to cease all communication and activity related to this account.

You may only contact me to provide the requested confirmation or if legally required to inform me of one of the exceptions noted above. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
In early to mid XXXX ( approximately ), I ordered a debit card from Fidelity for my cash management account. I was supposed to receive the card which was issued by BNY Mellon in mid to late XXXX. However, I never received the debit card in late XXXX. 

On XX/XX/2024, a {$690.00} debit card purchase was posted on my Fidelity Cash Management account with the card I never received. The purchase was made at a store I had never heard of or have any business with. I also never received a notification of card activation either. I then called Fidelity customer service immediately. Fidelity told me that they would be investigating, and would have updates in the next couple weeks. 

I then contacted my apartment 's management office about my possible missing mails. My management office told me that a mail theft has been caught on camera breaking into the mailroom in the middle of the night, and that they had already reported the crime to USPS and called the police. I later also reported identity theft and mail theft to USPS. 

About 2 weeks later, someone claiming to be investigating the case called me. The investigator asked me how someone could use both my debit card and ID card to make the purchase. I was stunned because as a victim of the crime, I have no knowledge on how it was committed. The investigator then asked me if I had ever been to the shop the purchase was made. I told the investigator I have never been there. The Investigator told me that they might reach out if they needed any more information. 

On the following week, I received a letter from BNY Mellon claiming the purchase was valid, and my fraud claim was denied. The letter was dated on XX/XX/2024, so BNY Mellon denied my claim right after the investigator called me. They never reached out to me again for any evidence or documents. 

I then contacted Fidelity customer service again, and they told me that I had to contact BNY Mellon directly which I did. However, BNY Mellon never picked up my phone call. 

On XX/XX/2024, I went to police department to report the crime since both Fidelity and BNY Mellon were unable to resolve my issues. The police department told me that I would need a statement mailed to me from BNY Mellon to open a case, but again, BNY Mellon never picked up my phone call.
Company: BANK OF NEW YORK MELLON CORPORATION, THE

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Consumer complaint narrative:
U.S.C. refers to Title 15 of the United States Code, which deals with commerce and trade. Title 15 includes various laws aimed at regulating business practices, protecting consumers, and promoting fair competition. It covers a broad range of topics such as credit reporting, antitrust laws, and consumer protection. 

Heres an overview of some key parts of 15 U.S.C. : 1. Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) - 15 U.S.C. 1681 The FCRA regulates how credit reporting agencies ( credit bureaus ) collect, use, and share consumer credit information. It ensures that credit reports are accurate and fair, providing protections for consumers against errors and misuse of their credit data. 

Consumer Rights : Consumers have the right to access their credit reports, dispute errors, and place fraud alerts or credit freezes on their files. 

Credit Report Access : Credit bureaus can only share reports with parties that have a legitimate reason, like lenders or insurers. 


2. Truth in Lending Act ( TILA ) - 15 U.S.C. 1601 et seq. 

TILA requires lenders to disclose important information about credit terms, such as the annual percentage rate ( APR ), fees, and the total cost of a loan. Its goal is to help consumers make informed decisions when borrowing. 

Disclosure : Lenders must provide clear and accurate information about loans. 

Consumer Protections : TILA aims to prevent deceptive lending practices and ensures that borrowers understand the full costs of credit. 


3. Equal Credit Opportunity Act ( ECOA ) - 15 U.S.C. 1691 The ECOA ensures that all consumers are treated equally in credit transactions. It prohibits discrimination based on race, color, religion, sex, marital status, age, or national origin. 

Fair Lending : Creditors must evaluate all applicants for credit based on their ability to repay, not personal characteristics like gender or race. 


4. Consumer Credit Protection Act ( CCPA ) - 15 U.S.C. 1601 et seq. 

The CCPA aims to protect consumers in credit transactions, including regulating credit reporting, debt collection, and other consumer finance practices. It is a broader law encompassing several provisions related to credit and lending. 

5. Credit Repair Organizations Act ( CROA ) - 15 U.S.C. 1679 The CROA regulates credit repair businesses to prevent fraud and misleading practices. It outlines the rights of consumers when dealing with credit repair services and prohibits organizations from making false claims. 

Consumer Protections : It requires credit repair companies to provide clear contracts and allows consumers to cancel services within three days. 


Enforcement : The laws under 15 U.S.C. are enforced by various federal agencies, including : Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ) : The FTC enforces consumer protection laws related to credit and business practices. 

Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) : The CFPB oversees financial institutions and credit bureaus to ensure compliance with these laws. 


Conclusion : 15 U.S.C. is a significant body of law that governs commerce and trade in the U.S., with a strong focus on protecting consumers in areas such as credit reporting, lending, and credit repair. It includes the FCRA, ECOA, and TILA, which are key to ensuring fair treatment, transparency, and privacy for consumers in financial transactions. 

15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) refers to a provision in the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), which regulates credit reporting practices and ensures the accuracy of information reported by credit bureaus. Specifically, 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) requires that credit reporting agencies ( credit bureaus ) take certain actions to ensure the accuracy of the information they report. 

Key Provision : 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) This section mandates that : Reasonable Procedures for Accuracy : Credit reporting agencies must " follow reasonable procedures to assure maximum possible accuracy '' of the information in the credit reports they generate. 

Preventing Inaccurate Reporting : This requires credit bureaus to adopt procedures that help avoid reporting inaccurate, outdated, or incomplete information in consumers ' credit reports. 


What This Means : Accuracy of Credit Reports : Credit bureaus are legally required to ensure that the data they report is accurate and complete, and they must take reasonable steps to verify information before reporting it. 

Consumer Protection : If a consumer identifies inaccurate information on their credit report, the credit bureau is obligated to investigate the dispute. Under the FCRA, the consumer has the right to challenge incorrect data, and the credit bureau must correct any errors upon verification.

Consumer complaint narrative:
" I am writing to formally file a complaint regarding unauthorized accounts that persist on my credit report despite my repeated efforts to have them removed. These accounts are causing significant damage to my financial reputation and overall well-being. It is evident that the inclusion of these fraudulent items violates 15 USC 1681b regarding permissible purposes, as the credit bureaus have no legitimate reason to report them without my explicit consent. Please refer to the attached file detailing these items I am disputing. 
The Fair Credit Reporting Act ( 15 U.S. Code 1681 ) says ( 1 ) The banking system is dependent upon fair and accurate credit reporting. Inaccurate credit reports directly impair the efficiency of the banking system, and unfair credit reporting methods undermine the public confidence, which is essential to the continued functioning of the banking system. So whenever there is a violation under the FCRA, it impairs the efficiency of the banking system. This is a violation of my privacy with my consumer report, since I control what is listed and what is not. In the event that any accounts are reported without my written consent, that is considered identity theft. ''

Consumer complaint narrative:
Good day! 
I am reaching out regarding several concerning accounts in my credit report that require investigation for a lawful resolution. Upon review, I identified inaccuracies and inconsistencies that violate the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ). The violations I have noted include : Violation of Timely Payments Regulations Violation of Finance Charge Determination Violation of United States Code Law ( TILA 15 U.S. Code 1666 ( b ) billing error ) I request that you provide proper evidence showing that I was late on this account, in compliance with Section 15 USC 1681a ( 2 ) Ai, 15 USC 1666b, and 1637 ( b ). If you can not supply the required evidence, you can not deem payment as late, which constitutes a violation of Section 15 USC 1681s-2. Please update the account as " PAID '' or " PAID AS AGREED. '' Additionally, I am filing this complaint due to the multiple inaccuracies in my report, which have negatively impacted my ability to secure credit. The violations that need prompt attention are : FCRA Section 616 - Civil Liability for Willful Noncompliance FCRA Section 603 ( 4 ) ( 2 ) ( A ) - Obligations with Respect to Disclosures of Personal Information FCRA Section 623 ( a ) ( 3 ) - Furnishing Deceptive Forms Violation of Credit Report Permissible Purposes Privacy Act violations U.S.C 552a ( g ) ( 1 ) ( A ) USC 1692e I demand verifiable proof, specifically the original consumer contract with my signature, for the accounts listed. Under the FCRA, unverified accounts must be removed if you can not provide this proof. Therefore, I insist that the accounts be VERIFIED or REMOVED immediately. 
Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Dispute and Request for Removal of Fraudulent Charge-Off Accounts from Experian Credit Report Dear Sir/Madam, I am writing to file a formal complaint and request the immediate removal of fraudulent charge-off accounts from my Experian credit report. As a victim of identity theft, I have been subjected to unauthorized accounts and transactions that have adversely affected my credit standing. In accordance with the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and Experian 's policies, these fraudulent entries must be removed to ensure the accuracy and integrity of my credit report. 

The details of the fraudulent accounts are as follows : XXXX. XXXX XXXX Number : XXXX - Balance : {$5900.00} - Balance Updated : XX/XX/XXXX - Credit Limit : {$5000.00} - Account Status : Closed - Date Opened : XX/XX/XXXX - Account Type : Credit Card XXXX. XXXX XXXX Number : XXXX - Balance : {$1300.00} - Balance Updated : XX/XX/XXXX - Credit Limit : {$1000.00} - Account Status : Closed - Date Opened : XX/XX/XXXX - Account Type : Credit Card XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Number : XXXX - Balance : {$16000.00} - Balance Updated : XX/XX/XXXX - Credit Limit : {$15000.00} - Account Status : Closed - Date Opened : XX/XX/XXXX - Account Type : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Number : XXXX - Balance : {$21000.00} - Balance Updated : XX/XX/XXXX - Credit Limit : {$20000.00} - Account Status : Closed - Date Opened : XX/XX/XXXX - Account Type : Credit Card This information is the result of identity theft and does not accurately reflect my credit history. I have also taken steps to have these accounts suppressed by XXXX XXXX XXXX, where they were deemed unverifiable. I have attached a copy of the identity theft report filed with the Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ), as well as the documentation from XXXX, for your reference. 

Under the FCRA, consumers are entitled to dispute any inaccurate information on their credit reports and to request its removal if proven to be fraudulent. Despite my previous attempts to resolve this matter directly with Experian, these fraudulent charge-off accounts continue to appear on my credit report, causing significant harm to my financial reputation. 

In light of the above, I kindly request the CFPB to intervene and ensure that Experian promptly investigates these disputed accounts and removes them from my credit report. I have attached copies of my identity theft report filed with the Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ), police reports, and any other relevant documentation to substantiate my claim. 

I trust that the CFPB will take swift and appropriate action to rectify this issue, ensuring that my credit report is accurate and reflects only legitimate transactions. 

Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Dispute and Request for Removal of Fraudulent Charge-Off Accounts from Experian Credit Report Dear Sir/Madam, I am writing to file a formal complaint and request the immediate removal of fraudulent charge-off accounts from my Experian credit report. As a victim of identity theft, I have been subjected to unauthorized accounts and transactions that have adversely affected my credit standing. In accordance with the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) and Experian 's policies, these fraudulent entries must be removed to ensure the accuracy and integrity of my credit report. 

The details of the fraudulent accounts are as follows : XXXX. XXXX XXXX Number : XXXX - Balance : {$5900.00} - Balance Updated : XX/XX/XXXX - Credit Limit : {$5000.00} - Account Status : Closed - Date Opened : XX/XX/XXXX - Account Type : Credit Card XXXX. XXXX XXXX Number : XXXX - Balance : {$1300.00} - Balance Updated : XX/XX/XXXX - Credit Limit : {$1000.00} - Account Status : Closed - Date Opened : XX/XX/XXXX - Account Type : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Number : XXXX - Balance : {$16000.00} - Balance Updated : XX/XX/XXXX - Credit Limit : {$15000.00} - Account Status : Closed - Date Opened : XX/XX/XXXX - Account Type : Credit Card XXXX. XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Number : XXXX - Balance : {$21000.00} - Balance Updated : XX/XX/XXXX - Credit Limit : {$20000.00} - Account Status : Closed - Date Opened : XX/XX/XXXX - Account Type : Credit Card This information is the result of identity theft and does not accurately reflect my credit history. I have also taken steps to have these accounts suppressed by XXXX XXXX XXXX, where they were deemed unverifiable. I have attached a copy of the identity theft report filed with the Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ), as well as the documentation from XXXX, for your reference. 

Under the FCRA, consumers are entitled to dispute any inaccurate information on their credit reports and to request its removal if proven to be fraudulent. Despite my previous attempts to resolve this matter directly with Experian, these fraudulent charge-off accounts continue to appear on my credit report, causing significant harm to my financial reputation. 

In light of the above, I kindly request the CFPB to intervene and ensure that Experian promptly investigates these disputed accounts and removes them from my credit report. I have attached copies of my identity theft report filed with the Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ), police reports, and any other relevant documentation to substantiate my claim. 

I trust that the CFPB will take swift and appropriate action to rectify this issue, ensuring that my credit report is accurate and reflects only legitimate transactions. 

Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally request the deletion of an unverifiable account from my credit report under the provisions of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), 15 U.S.C. 1681 et seq. Specifically, this pertains to the account identified as a {$720.00} charge-off with XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX 
After disputing this account with XXXX, their investigation was completed on XX/XX/2024. Following the investigation, XXXX deleted this account from my credit report, as the information could not be verified. If XXXX has removed the account due to its unverifiability, I urge you to take similar action and remove this account from my credit report promptly. 
Under the FCRA, all credit reporting agencies are required to ensure that the information on consumer reports is accurate, complete, and verifiable. Specifically : Section 611 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) of the FCRA mandates that credit reporting agencies conduct a reasonable investigation of disputed information.

If the disputed information can not be verified as accurate, Section 611 ( a ) ( 5 ) ( A ) requires the credit reporting agency to delete it from the consumers credit file. 
Furthermore, under Section 623 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ), furnishers of information must not provide information that they know or have reasonable cause to believe is inaccurate. 
Since XXXX has deemed this account unverifiable and deleted it, I expect the same resolution from your agency. If this unverifiable debt is not removed within 30 days from the receipt of this letter, I reserve the right to pursue further legal action under the FCRA. 
Failure to comply with FCRA requirements may subject your organization to statutory damages, actual damages, court costs, and reasonable attorney fees under Section 616 and Section 617 of the FCRA. Additionally, if willful noncompliance is found, I may be entitled to punitive damages.

To ensure a clear record of this request, I have attached the relevant documentation, including confirmation from XXXX regarding the deletion of the account. 
Please confirm in writing that this account has been deleted from my credit report or provide a detailed explanation of your investigation findings. I expect a response within the time frame outlined by the FCRA. 
Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter. 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX Enclosures : 1. Copy of confirmation from XXXX regarding account deletion 2. Copy of my credit report showing the disputed account ( if applicable ) 3. Any additional supporting documentation

Consumer complaint narrative:

Consumer complaint narrative:
Dear Bank of America, I am writing to address discrepancies in the reporting of my account ( Account Number : XXXX ) on my credit report. Upon review, I have identified a significant inconsistency regarding the account 's status that requires immediate attention. 

The account is simultaneously reported as " charged off '' and " past due '' with a balance of {$820.00}. This reporting is inconsistent and misleading, as a charged-off account indicates the debt has been written off by the creditor as a loss, and it should no longer accrue a past-due status. 

Violations of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) : 1. Inaccurate and Misleading Reporting : Under the FCRA, creditors are required to ensure that information furnished to credit reporting agencies is accurate and not misleading. The dual status of " charged off '' and " past due '' creates confusion and may unfairly harm my credit profile.

2. Failure to Provide Clear and Consistent Information : This inconsistency violates FCRA provisions that mandate clear and accurate reporting of account statuses.

3. Double Penalty Impact : Reporting the account as both charged off and past due results in a negative double impact on my creditworthiness, which is unfair and improper.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Identity Theft Dispute Pursuant to FCRA 605B To Whom It May Concern, This letter serves as a formal demand to rectify and suppress all fraudulent and unauthorized information on my credit report, as detailed herein and pursuant to the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) 605B. I demand immediate action to address the aforementioned inaccuracies. Your compliance is expected to prevent further harm and uphold your obligations under federal law. 

Pursuant to FCRA 605B, you are legally required to block all fraudulent accounts and remove unauthorized inquiries within 4 days of receiving this dispute and the herein-mentioned documentation. 

As previously referenced, I was a victim of the Equifax data breach, one of the largest breaches in history, which compromised the personal information of millions of individuals, including sensitive data such as Social Security numbers and financial records. This breach most definitely played a critical role in the unauthorized access and misuse of my personal information, resulting in the fraudulent accounts and inquiries outlined below. 

Fraudulent Accounts ( I dispute the following ) : XXXX : Date Opened : XX/XX/XXXX, Amount : {$1200.00} XXXX XXXX : Date Opened : XX/XX/XXXX, Amount : {$560.00} XXXX XXXX XXXX : Date Opened : XX/XX/XXXX, Amount : {$0.00} XXXX : Date Opened : XX/XX/XXXX, Amount : {$590.00} XXXX  XXXX XXXX  : Date Opened : XX/XX/XXXX, Amount : {$640.00} Unrelated Unauthorized Inquiries ( I dispute the following ) : XXXX XXXX XXXX : Date of Inquiry : XX/XX/XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX : Date of Inquiry : XX/XX/XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX : Date of Inquiry : XX/XX/XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Date of Inquiry : XX/XX/XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX : Date of Inquiry : XX/XX/XXXX The harm caused by these unrecognized and unauthorized accounts and inquiries has been significant, severely damaging my creditworthiness, financial stability, and mental well-being. These inaccuracies have magnified the financial and emotional toll on my family as we recover from a natural disaster. A strong storm hit our area on a rainy day, causing the roof of our home to rupture and sustain significant damage. As a result, rainwater poured into the house, damaging the structure, our belongings, and essential property. The aforementioned fraudulent accounts and inquiries have further delayed my ability to rebuild stability and provide for my family. 

It is also critical to note that, in my efforts to resolve these inaccuracies, I hired multiple reputable credit repair companies, fully authorized to act on my behalf as permitted by law. Despite this, the credit bureaus employed various cunning and obstructive methods to stall their work, disregarding my lawful authorization and delaying necessary corrections to my credit report. Such actions have magnified the harm caused by the herein-detailed inaccuracies and undermined my rights under the FCRA. 

Failure to address this matter in a timely and lawful manner will result in formal complaints to the 1Attorney General 's office, as well as potential legal action to seek damages for the harm caused. 

Enclosed, you will find the following supporting documents for your records and in compliance with your identification requirements : 1. A copy of my FTC Identity Theft Report ( # XXXX ). 


2. A copy of my government-issued ID.

3. Proof of address. 



Please direct all correspondence regarding this dispute to my email address at XXXX. I request written confirmation that the requested actions have been completed within 4 days of your receipt of this letter, as required under FCRA 605B. Failure to comply herein constitutes a violation of federal law and will result in escalated legal actions. 

Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

The CFPA empowers the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) to regulate these practices, known as UDAAPs ( Unfair, Deceptive, or Abusive Acts or Practices ), in consumer financial products.

Capital One 's actions are significantly harming my credit score, which constitutes an unfair or deceptive act. Such practices undermine the integrity of the credit reporting system and negatively impact my ability to manage my financial well-being.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Consumer complaint narrative:
U.S.C. refers to Title 15 of the United States Code, which deals with commerce and trade. Title 15 includes various laws aimed at regulating business practices, protecting consumers, and promoting fair competition. It covers a broad range of topics such as credit reporting, antitrust laws, and consumer protection. 

Heres an overview of some key parts of 15 U.S.C. : 1. Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) - 15 U.S.C. 1681 The FCRA regulates how credit reporting agencies ( credit bureaus ) collect, use, and share consumer credit information. It ensures that credit reports are accurate and fair, providing protections for consumers against errors and misuse of their credit data. 

Consumer Rights : Consumers have the right to access their credit reports, dispute errors, and place fraud alerts or credit freezes on their files.

Credit Report Access : Credit bureaus can only share reports with parties that have a legitimate reason, like lenders or insurers. 


2. Truth in Lending Act ( TILA ) - 15 U.S.C. 1601 et seq. 

TILA requires lenders to disclose important information about credit terms, such as the annual percentage rate ( APR ), fees, and the total cost of a loan. Its goal is to help consumers make informed decisions when borrowing. 

Disclosure : Lenders must provide clear and accurate information about loans. 

Consumer Protections : TILA aims to prevent deceptive lending practices and ensures that borrowers understand the full costs of credit. 


3. Equal Credit Opportunity Act ( ECOA ) - 15 U.S.C. 1691 The ECOA ensures that all consumers are treated equally in credit transactions. It prohibits discrimination based on race, color, religion, sex, marital status, age, or national origin. 

Fair Lending : Creditors must evaluate all applicants for credit based on their ability to repay, not personal characteristics like gender or race. 


4. Consumer Credit Protection Act ( CCPA ) - 15 U.S.C. 1601 et seq. 

The CCPA aims to protect consumers in credit transactions, including regulating credit reporting, debt collection, and other consumer finance practices. It is a broader law encompassing several provisions related to credit and lending. 

5. Credit Repair Organizations Act ( CROA ) - 15 U.S.C. 1679 The CROA regulates credit repair businesses to prevent fraud and misleading practices. It outlines the rights of consumers when dealing with credit repair services and prohibits organizations from making false claims. 

Consumer Protections : It requires credit repair companies to provide clear contracts and allows consumers to cancel services within three days. 


Enforcement : The laws under 15 U.S.C. are enforced by various federal agencies, including : Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ) : The FTC enforces consumer protection laws related to credit and business practices. 

Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) : The CFPB oversees financial institutions and credit bureaus to ensure compliance with these laws. 


Conclusion : 15 U.S.C. is a significant body of law that governs commerce and trade in the U.S., with a strong focus on protecting consumers in areas such as credit reporting, lending, and credit repair. It includes the FCRA, ECOA, and TILA, which are key to ensuring fair treatment, transparency, and privacy for consumers in financial transactions. 

15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) refers to a provision in the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), which regulates credit reporting practices and ensures the accuracy of information reported by credit bureaus. Specifically, 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) requires that credit reporting agencies ( credit bureaus ) take certain actions to ensure the accuracy of the information they report. 

Key Provision : 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) This section mandates that : Reasonable Procedures for Accuracy : Credit reporting agencies must " follow reasonable procedures to assure maximum possible accuracy '' of the information in the credit reports they generate. Preventing Inaccurate Reporting : This re
quires credit bureaus to adopt procedures that help avoid reporting inaccurate, outdated, or incomplete information in consumers ' credit reports. 


What This Means : Accuracy of Credit Reports : Credit bureaus are legally required to ensure that the data they report is accurate and complete, and they must take reasonable steps to verify information before reporting it. 

Consumer Protection : If a consumer identifies inaccurate information on their credit report, the credit bureau is obligated to investigate the dispute. Under the FCRA, the consumer has the right to challenge incorrect data, and the credit bureau must correct any errors upon verification.

Product: Checking or savings account
Consumer complaint narrative:
I opened a savings account online, and after completing the account setup, I mailed a check on XXXX XXXX, XXXX, along with a letter of instruction to deposit the funds into the newly opened account. The check was written to me by XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX After the check was deposited, I contacted the bank and was informed that the check would be held until XXXX XXXX, XXXX. 

On XXXX XXXX, XXXX, my account showed an available balance of ** $ XXXX, which reflected the full amount of the check. However, when I attempted to transfer funds from my account, I received the following message : * '' You can't make transfers at this time. Your account functionality is limited. Please call XXXX. " * I called the number provided and spoke with a customer service agent. After asking me a few questions, the agent placed me on hold. When they returned, the agent informed me that my account had been closed. When I asked when the account was closed, the agent stated that it was closed that very day. 

I then inquired about the funds remaining in the account. The agent told me that a check would be mailed to XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX I expressed my confusion, stating that I had been the one who mailed the check, and it did not make sense to return it to XXXX  XXXX XXXX. The agent could not provide any further explanation, but mentioned that the account was closed for *business reasons* and offered no additional details. 

This situation has caused significant hardship for me. The funds in that account represented my entire savings, and I am now unable to pay my rent and other bills. I feel as though I am being treated unfairly and without proper explanation, and this has caused considerable distress. 

I am seeking clarification and resolution of this matter as soon as possible.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Good day! 
I am reaching out regarding several concerning accounts in my credit report that require investigation for a lawful resolution. Upon review, I identified inaccuracies and inconsistencies that violate the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ). The violations I have noted include : Violation of Timely Payments Regulations Violation of Finance Charge Determination Violation of United States Code Law ( TILA 15 U.S. Code 1666 ( b ) billing error ) I request that you provide proper evidence showing that I was late on this account, in compliance with Section 15 USC 1681a ( 2 ) Ai, 15 USC 1666b, and 1637 ( b ). If you can not supply the required evidence, you can not deem payment as late, which constitutes a violation of Section 15 USC 1681s-2. Please update the account as " PAID '' or " PAID AS AGREED. '' Additionally, I am filing this complaint due to the multiple inaccuracies in my report, which have negatively impacted my ability to secure credit. The violations that need prompt attention are : FCRA Section 616 - Civil Liability for Willful Noncompliance FCRA Section 603 ( 4 ) ( 2 ) ( A ) - Obligations with Respect to Disclosures of Personal Information FCRA Section 623 ( a ) ( 3 ) - Furnishing Deceptive Forms Violation of Credit Report Permissible Purposes Privacy Act violations U.S.C 552a ( g ) ( 1 ) ( A ) USC 1692e I demand verifiable proof, specifically the original consumer contract with my signature, for the accounts listed. Under the FCRA, unverified accounts must be removed if you can not provide this proof. Therefore, I insist that the accounts be VERIFIED or REMOVED immediately.

Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Consumer complaint narrative:
Dear Consumer Financial Protection Bureau Team, I hope this email finds you well, and I want to begin by expressing my appreciation for the invaluable work your organization does in protecting consumers like me. Its reassuring to know that there is a dedicated team ensuring fairness and accuracy in the financial industry. 

I am reaching out regarding an issue I have encountered with my TransUnion credit report. I recently discovered that my date of birth is inaccurately listed as XXXX, making me appear XXXX XXXX XXXX, when in fact, I was born in XXXX and am currently XXXX XXXX XXXX. 

While I understand that TransUnion handles large amounts of data and occasional errors can occur, I have been unsuccessful in my attempts to resolve this issue directly with them. Despite providing documentation that verifies my correct date of birth, they informed me that they are unable to make the necessary correction.

This error, though it may seem minor, has the potential to create significant challenges for me, including difficulties with identity verification, financial applications, and maintaining an accurate credit profile. I value the integrity of my credit report and wish to address this matter promptly. 

I kindly request your assistance in facilitating a resolution with TransUnion. I have attached copies of my government-issued ID and other supporting documents to verify my correct date of birth for your review. 

I deeply respect the role TransUnion plays in providing reliable credit information, and my intention is simply to work collaboratively to correct this discrepancy. I am confident that, with your guidance, this issue can be resolved efficiently. 

Thank you again for the vital work you do to advocate for consumers. I look forward to hearing from you and am happy to provide any additional information if needed. 

Warm regards, XXXX XXXX [ XXXX ] XXXX XXXX

Product: Money transfer, virtual currency, or money service
Consumer complaint narrative:
XXXX XXXX I did a search by XXXX for discounted medical supply and a top result was XXXX I did a further search on that website to find an anonymous supplier for these items that were promised to be cheap and sent very quickly. This unknown party has my name, mailing address and phone number. I absolutely refused to provide any further information such as social security number or bank account details. I was requested by this party to pay third party wires to names that all had a shared domestic address and Wells Fargo account but different names. I was coached to say this was friend repayment which was on the memo of a series of wire out transfers that flagged my personal account by fraud. 

The tactic used by this party pay by wire to have the package released and anything paid would be reimbursed to me by check. I received an email with check images that I incorrectly thought I could deposit. The check was fake, and it came from a bogus company name and address also held at Wells Fargo. Prior to deposit I checked to see if this was a valid routing and account number ; the system we use for check deposit verified the case. I honestly thought it would clear. 

This party used text message numbers and emails to communicate with me at the end of each day to send more money ; the delay each day was adding to some fees/taxes that prevented anything from being sent. 

These people have my personal cell phone, home address and email. It was under the promise of items purchased that I never received and threats of blackmail if I didn't continue to pay. 

I have filed written complaints to my sending banks and unable to have Wells Fargo conduct an internal investigation on my behalf.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Good day! 
I am reaching out regarding several concerning accounts in my credit report that require investigation for a lawful resolution. Upon review, I identified inaccuracies and inconsistencies that violate the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ). The violations I have noted include : Violation of Timely Payments Regulations Violation of Finance Charge Determination Violation of United States Code Law ( TILA 15 U.S. Code 1666 ( b ) billing error ) I request that you provide proper evidence showing that I was late on this account, in compliance with Section 15 USC 1681a ( 2 ) Ai, 15 USC 1666b, and 1637 ( b ). If you can not supply the required evidence, you can not deem payment as late, which constitutes a violation of Section 15 USC 1681s-2. Please update the account as " PAID '' or " PAID AS AGREED. '' Additionally, I am filing this complaint due to the multiple inaccuracies in my report, which have negatively impacted my ability to secure credit. The violations that need prompt attention are : FCRA Section 616 - Civil Liability for Willful Noncompliance FCRA Section 603 ( 4 ) ( 2 ) ( A ) - Obligations with Respect to Disclosures of Personal Information FCRA Section 623 ( a ) ( 3 ) - Furnishing Deceptive Forms Violation of Credit Report Permissible Purposes Privacy Act violations U.S.C 552a ( g ) ( 1 ) ( A ) USC 1692e I demand verifiable proof, specifically the original consumer contract with my signature, for the accounts listed. Under the FCRA, unverified accounts must be removed if you can not provide this proof. Therefore, I insist that the accounts be VERIFIED or REMOVED immediately. 
Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter.

It is evident that the inclusion of these fraudulent items violates 15 USC 1681b regarding permissible purposes, as the credit bureaus have no legitimate reason to report them without my explicit consent. Please refer to the attached file detailing these items I am disputing.

The Fair Credit Reporting Act ( 15 U.S. Code 1681 ) says ( 1 ) The banking system is dependent upon fair and accurate credit reporting. Inaccurate credit reports directly impair the efficiency of the banking system, and unfair credit reporting methods undermine the public confidence, which is essential to the continued functioning of the banking system. So whenever there is a violation under the FCRA, it impairs the efficiency of the banking system. This is a violation of my privacy with my consumer report, since I control what is listed and what is not. In the event that any accounts are reported without my written consent, that is considered identity theft. ''

Product: Debt collection
Issue: Attempts to collect debt not owed
Consumer complaint narrative:
Recently I did an investigation on my credit report and found several items on there to be inaccurate. 
Under 15 U.S. Code 1681e ( b ) Accuracy of report Whenever a consumer reporting agency prepares a consumer report, it shall follow reasonable procedures to assure the maximum possible accuracy of the information concerning the individual about whom the report relates. 
15 U.S. Code 1681i ( 5 ) Treatment of inaccurate or unverifiable information ( A ) In general if, after any reinvestigation under paragraph ( 1 ) of any information disputed by a consumer, an item of the information is found to be inaccurate or incomplete or can not be verified, the consumer reporting agency shalli ) promptly delete that item of information from the file of the consumer, or modify that item of information, as appropriate, based on the results of the reinvestigation; and ( ii ) promptly notify the furnisher of that information that the information has been modified or deleted from the file of the consumer.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Consumer complaint narrative: Under 15 USC 1681i ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) subject to subsection ( f ) and except as provided in subsection ( g ), If the completeness or accuracy of any item of information contained in a consumer 's file at a consumer reporting agency is disputed by the consumer and the consumer notifies the agency directly or indirectly through a reseller, of such dispute, the agency shall, free of charge, conduct a reasonable reinvestigation to determine whether the disputed information is inaccurate and record the current status of the disputed information, or delete the item from the file in accordance with paragraph ( 5 ), before the end of the 30-day period beginning on the date on which the agency receives the notice of the dispute from the consumer or reseller. Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Credit card
Sub-product: General-purpose credit card or charge card
Sub-issue: Account sold or transferred to another company
Consumer complaint narrative:
In XX/XX/year>, I had my phone and wallet stolen. And all the other credit card companies followed, normal procedures and reimbursed. The charges that were made by the individuals that stole the credit cards and debit cards. I filed a police report that said my accounts it all been hacked. It was part of a broader crime ring in XXXX XXXX and in fact, XXXX has changed it software since so that you cant change your password without an hour approval. For just that reason so that people couldnt shadow you get your six digit passcode to your XXXX and then get access to all of your accounts Plus since they stole my wallet they went to the US Postal Service and bought things for a dollar and asked for {$1000.00} of cash back during this chaotic 8 hours from XXXX XXXX  to XXXX. They sent an email to my wife who is a joint account owner asking whether this XXXX dollar withdrawal from an ATM was a proper charge and her not knowing and it being early in the morning and me being asleep in XXXX XXXX said yes. So when I went to file the claims with Chase Bank, they ultimately were all rejected under the presumption that I was behaving fraudulently. I subsequently sent them a copy of the police report and an explanation for which I never received a response and within a few months Chase had closed all of my accounts both a credit card thats linked to a United Airlines account and my bank account at Chase. At the time, I decided it didnt matter and I had other cards. 

For background, I have a over XXXX credit score, I have a net worth in access of seven digits, and Ive never missed a payment on any of my credit cards or mortgages or any other lending based account. 

I thought nothing of it until I recently was given an offer to open it Chase United MasterCard via my United app because the points count towards your status on the airline and they accepted and issued me a new credit card and then this month I received a letter, which is dated XX/XX/XXXX saying they were going to close the credit card account. 

I find this anti-competitive behavior from what is largely a monopolistic bank chase, the largest bank in the country that they have the power to turn off your accounts and enclose your credit cards without any explanation whatsoever, and then on top of it that they would issue the card and let you have it for six weeks and then somehow in their back office process to decide that once again you cant own any accounts with Chase Manhattan bank, which is the largest bank in the country without giving me any explanation whatsoever And not responding to my letters. So most of me thinks its their loss but at some point, the Chase company needs to have some responsibility and oversight for their credit behavior when I clearly have sent them evidence that I was robbed that Ive already absorbed {$5000.00} worth of charges because they were the card that allowed the most Set of ridiculous charges including three transactions for {$990.00} as cash back for the US postal system that this behavior is inappropriate given my 25 to 30 history with the bank and my credit score and the fact that I sent them a letter, for which they never responded, that had the police report and it was an actual theft that I wasnt trying to scam them out of the money

Product: Credit card
Sub-product: General-purpose credit card or charge card
Consumer complaint narrative:
Dear CFPB, I am filing a formal complaint against Synchrony Banks XXXX for unauthorized charges and account mismanagement. 

We used XXXX for a XXXX interest-free automated payment plan with our veterinarian to XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX. All payments were processed automatically through Synchrony Banks system, and we made the final payment on XX/XX/XXXX. After completing the last payment, we discovered an unexplained balance of {$230.00}. 

When we contacted CareCredit, we were informed that this balance was due to a Card Security fee. This fee was neither disclosed during the application process nor explained afterward. We were not informed of its purpose or calculation. The card was used exclusively by the veterinarian, and all payments followed Synchrony Banks automated schedule. We neither authorized nor knowingly agreed to this fee. 

To resolve the issue, I contacted customer service multiple times, engaged in live chats, and was transferred repeatedly between the credit card and " Card Security '' departments. Despite these efforts, no one provided a clear explanation for the charges. 

I was assured by several representatives that the {$230.00} charge was under review and that no interest or penalties would accrue during the process. Yet, on XX/XX/XXXX, we were charged an additional {$450.00}, with claims that the balance was unpaid. This is absurdwe had set up automatic payments to ensure all balances were paid on time, but this unexplained Card Security fee caused Synchrony Bank to violate the terms of the 6-month interest-free program. 

This reflects serious mismanagement : 1. Lack of transparency : The Card Security fee was never disclosed or explained. 
2. Failure of automated payment handling : The charges contradict the agreed plan. 
3. Conflicting information : Charges were applied despite assurances. 
4. Customer service failure : Multiple representatives failed to resolve the issue. 

I fulfilled my obligations in good faith and trusted their system. I expect a prompt resolution of this issue or will escalate further to protect my consumer rights. 

Sincerely,
Company public response: Company has responded to the consumer and the CFPB and chooses not to provide a public response

Consumer complaint narrative: XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX XX/XX/year> This CFPB complaint has been led to request pursuant to FCRA 605B ( 15 U.S.C. 1681c-2 ) My XXXX report consist of a fraudulent account with Ally Bank under account ending in XXXX. I demand that the aforementioned fraudulent items be removed from each of my consumer credit reports and that all collection activity related to said items cease pursuant to my rights within the FCRA and FDCPA laws. This accounts have resulted in several fraudulent hard inquiries and fraudulent collections appearing on my consumer XXXX report. I do not recognize the aforementioned account all of the aforementioned accounts, collections, and hard inquiries are the result of identity theft and fraud. I have attached a copy of FTC Identity Theft Criminal Complaint # XXXX as proof from the US Federal Trade Commission that all of the aforementioned consumer credit accounts, collections, and hard inquiries are the result of identity theft and fraud. I have contacted this company more than 20 times to not get any assistance with this matter. I have proof of all my attempts that I sent by certified mail. I finally spoke with someone a couple weeks ago and was told I would be getting information to get this account investigated and removed to only get a blank if theft affidavit. Not to mention that I have already sent to them several times. This company has really just been running me around with no intention to help me get this resolved.

You and your inaccurate reporting have damaged my livelihood. 15 U.S. Code 1681s2 - Responsibilities of furnishers of information to consumer reporting agencies ( a ) DUTY OF FURNISHERS OF INFORMATION TO PROVIDE ACCURATE INFORMATION 1 ) PROHIBITION ( A ) Reporting information with actual knowledge of errors A person shall not furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate. Duty : a moral or legal obligation ; a responsibility Accurate : correct in all details ; exact. PROHIBITION : a law or regulation forbidding something As Defined by The IRS Even if you didn't receive a Form 1099-C, you must report canceled debt as gross income on your tax return. The IRS Clearly defines a charge off as Gross or Ordinary income, INCOME DOES NOT GET REPORTED ON THE CONSUMER REPORT which in fact makes your reporting of this account inaccurate! By Definition The IRS Clearly says a Cancelled debt or Charge off is Income. The reporting of this account as a debt is in accurate. 15 USC 1681 s-2 Says you are a furnisher of information to a consumer reporting agency. You ARE PROHIBITED BY LAW to furnish inaccurate information. I demand you to Cease and Desist the reporting of incorrect/ in accurate information immediately. 15 USC 1681 s-2 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) A person shall not furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate You are hereby put on NOTICE that you are furnishing incorrect inaccurate information. The lender must file Form 1099-C and send you a copy if the amount of debt canceled is {$600.00} or more and the lender is a financial institution, credit union , federal government agency, or other applicable entity as discussed earlier in chapter 1. The above paragraph is taken directly from the IRS 2021 publication. SEND ME MY FORM 1099-C that you should have sent when you Filled the account as a canceled debt. My Address is listed below! 15 U.S. Code 1681s2 ( a ) DUTY OF FURNISHERS OF INFORMATION TO PROVIDE ACCURATE INFORMATION 1 ) PROHIBITION ( B ) Reporting information after notice and confirmation of errors A person shall not furnish information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if ( i ) the person has been notified by the consumer, at the address specified by the person for such notices, that specific information is inaccurate ; and ( ii ) the information is, in fact, inaccurate. In conclusion I have shown you and you have been put on notice that you are reporting inaccurate information. The information is, in fact, inaccurate. The continued reporting of this inaccurate information is a clear violation of the Law 15 USC 1681 s-2 of your responsibilities as a furnisher of information. You have caused me and my family severe harm due to your negligence and inaccurate reporting. This is a final opportunity to Cure and DELETE This Erroneous, inaccurate account from my Consumer report. YOU HAVE 10 Calendar days to DELETE THIS ACOOUNT FROM MY CONSUMER REPORTS!

Consumer complaint narrative:
This formal complaint concerns unauthorized inquiries appearing on my credit report, made without my consent and lacking a permissible purpose under the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ). These inquiries are negatively impacting my credit profile and do not meet the FCRAs requirements for accessing a consumers credit report without express authorization. 
Details of Disputed Inquiries : The following inquiries are disputed, as verified by the creditors, who confirmed they were conducted without my knowledge or authorization : Creditor Name : XXXX XXXX XX/XX/XXXX Creditor Name : XXXX XXXX XX/XX/XXXX Creditor Name : XXXX XX/XX/XXXX ( Repeat for each disputed inquiry ) Legal Basis for Removal : Under the FCRA, specifically Section 604 ( 15 U.S.C. 1681b ), access to a credit report is only permissible when explicit consumer consent or a clearly permissible purpose exists. The listed inquiries do not meet these legal requirements. Additionally, under Section 611 ( a ) ( 5 ) ( 15 U.S.C. 1681i ( a ) ( 5 ) ), any unverifiable information must be promptly removed from the credit report. 
I have attempted to resolve this matter directly with the credit bureau by submitting a formal dispute letter on [ XX/XX/XXXX ]. However, I have not received an adequate response or the removal of the unauthorized inquiries, which I believe constitutes non-compliance with FCRA provisions. 
Supporting Case Law for Removal : Legal precedents reinforce the need for removal of unauthorized inquiries in the absence of a permissible purpose. In XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX ( XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX ), the XXXX XXXX ruled that accessing a credit report without explicit consumer consent or a legitimate purpose constitutes a violation of the FCRA. Furthermore, XXXX XXXX XXXX, XXXX ( XXXX XXXX XXXXXXXX ) reaffirms that credit bureaus are obligated to remove all inaccurate or unverifiable information.

Consumer complaint narrative:
Subject : Dispute of Inaccurate Information on Credit Report and violation to the Fair credit reporting act. 
Complaint Summary : I am submitting this complaint against Equifax regarding the inaccurate information reported on my credit report, which violates the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ). 
On [ Date of Credit Report ], I discovered discrepancies in the following account ( s ) : Account Name : XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX Under Section 611 of the FCRA, I have the right to dispute inaccuracies and request prompt investigation. I formally requested a reinvestigation of the account information and cited relevant sections of the FCRA, including : 1. Section 609 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) : Requirement for verification of accounts through original documentation. 
2. Section 611 : Right to dispute inaccuracies and request investigation. 
3. Section 623 ( a ) ( 5 ) : Removal of unverifiable information dont validated for creditor Original. 
4. 15 U.S. Code 1681e ( b ), which requires that the procedures for including information in credit reports ensure maximum possible accuracy Despite my request, Equifax has failed to conduct a thorough investigation or resolve these discrepancies within the required timeframe of 30 days. This negligence has led to the continued reporting of false information, which has negatively impacted my creditworthiness. 
In my request, I emphasized that any unverifiable information should be removed from my credit report INMEDEDIATLY within the mandated 30-day period, as established in 15 U.S. Code 1681i. Additionally, I referenced 15 U.S. Code 1681e ( b ), which requires that the procedures for including information in credit reports ensure maximum possible accuracy. Furthermore, under 15 U.S. Code 1681s-2, furnishers of information are required to investigate and correct inaccurate information upon notice of a dispute. 
Additional Information : Attached documents : driver 's id proof of address social security letter to the credit bureau images of each account with XXXX

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Consumer complaint narrative:
U.S.C. refers to Title 15 of the United States Code, which deals with commerce and trade. Title 15 includes various laws aimed at regulating business practices, protecting consumers, and promoting fair competition. It covers a broad range of topics such as credit reporting, antitrust laws, and consumer protection. 

Heres an overview of some key parts of 15 U.S.C. : 1. Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ) - 15 U.S.C. 1681 The FCRA regulates how credit reporting agencies ( credit bureaus ) collect, use, and share consumer credit information. It ensures that credit reports are accurate and fair, providing protections for consumers against errors and misuse of their credit data. 

Consumer Rights : Consumers have the right to access their credit reports, dispute errors, and place fraud alerts or credit freezes on their files. 

Credit Report Access : Credit bureaus can only share reports with parties that have a legitimate reason, like lenders or insurers. 


2. Truth in Lending Act ( TILA ) - 15 U.S.C. 1601 et seq. 

TILA requires lenders to disclose important information about credit terms, such as the annual percentage rate ( APR ), fees, and the total cost of a loan. Its goal is to help consumers make informed decisions when borrowing. 

Disclosure : Lenders must provide clear and accurate information about loans. 

Consumer Protections : TILA aims to prevent deceptive lending practices and ensures that borrowers understand the full costs of credit. 


3. Equal Credit Opportunity Act ( ECOA ) - 15 U.S.C. 1691 The ECOA ensures that all consumers are treated equally in credit transactions. It prohibits discrimination based on race, color, religion, sex, marital status, age, or national origin. 

Fair Lending : Creditors must evaluate all applicants for credit based on their ability to repay, not personal characteristics like gender or race. 


4. Consumer Credit Protection Act ( CCPA ) - 15 U.S.C. 1601 et seq. 

The CCPA aims to protect consumers in credit transactions, including regulating credit reporting, debt collection, and other consumer finance practices. It is a broader law encompassing several provisions related to credit and lending. 

5. Credit Repair Organizations Act ( CROA ) - 15 U.S.C. 1679 The CROA regulates credit repair businesses to prevent fraud and misleading practices. It outlines the rights of consumers when dealing with credit repair services and prohibits organizations from making false claims. 

Consumer Protections : It requires credit repair companies to provide clear contracts and allows consumers to cancel services within three days.

Enforcement : The laws under 15 U.S.C. are enforced by various federal agencies, including : Federal Trade Commission ( FTC ) : The FTC enforces consumer protection laws related to credit and business practices. 

Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) : The CFPB oversees financial institutions and credit bureaus to ensure compliance with these laws. 


Conclusion : 15 U.S.C. is a significant body of law that governs commerce and trade in the U.S., with a strong focus on protecting consumers in areas such as credit reporting, lending, and credit repair. It includes the FCRA, ECOA, and TILA, which are key to ensuring fair treatment, transparency, and privacy for consumers in financial transactions. 

15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) refers to a provision in the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), which regulates credit reporting practices and ensures the accuracy of information reported by credit bureaus. Specifically, 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) requires that credit reporting agencies ( credit bureaus ) take certain actions to ensure the accuracy of the information they report. 

Key Provision : 15 U.S.C. 1681e ( b ) This section mandates that : Reasonable Procedures for Accuracy : Credit reporting agencies must " follow reasonable procedures to assure maximum possible accuracy '' of the information in the credit reports they generate. 

Preventing Inaccurate Reporting : This requires credit bureaus to adopt procedures that help avoid reporting inaccurate, outdated, or incomplete information in consumers ' credit reports. 


What This Means : Accuracy of Credit Reports : Credit bureaus are legally required to ensure that the data they report is accurate and complete, and they must take reasonable steps to verify information before reporting it. 

Consumer Protection : If a consumer identifies inaccurate information on their credit report, the credit bureau is obligated to investigate the dispute. Under the FCRA, the consumer has the right to challenge incorrect data, and the credit bureau must correct any errors upon verification.

Consumer complaint narrative:
In accordance with the Fair Credit Reporting act. The List of accounts below has violated my federally protected consumer rights to privacy and confidentiality under 15 USC 1681.

15 U.S.C 1681 section 602 A. States I have the right to privacy.

15 U.S.C 1681 Section 604 A Section 2 : It also states a consumer reporting agency can not furnish a account without my written instructions 15 U.S.C 1681c. ( a ) ( 5 ) Section States : no consumer reporting agency may make any consumer report containing any of the following items of information Any other adverse item of information, other than records of convictions of crimes which antedates the report by more than seven years.

15 U.S.C. 1681s-2 ( A ) ( 1 ) A person shall not furnish any information relating to a consumer to any consumer reporting agency if the person knows or has reasonable cause to believe that the information is inaccurate.

Consumer complaint narrative:
To Whom It May Concern, I strongly disagree with your investigation response. The following incorrect items still remain on my credit report, despite your investigation. I request an immediate re-investigation of these items for valid reasons. These inaccuracies are severely damaging to my credit score.

1. Validate Account XXXX XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX Account Number : XXXX Please supply information on how you have verified this item. 


Furthermore, in accordance with The Fair Credit Reporting Act, Public Law 91-506, Title VI, Section 611, Subsection A-D, I demand that you provide tangible evidence that the information was verified, rather than a computer-generated confirmation. 

Please provide the following : The names and business addresses of each individual you verified the information with above, so that I can follow up. 

The date on which you contacted the individual furnishers of information. 

The method of communication you used to verify the information. 

I would also like to know if the furnisher provided you with my SSN, address, or XXXX. 

Please send me an updated credit report once you have completed your investigation and made the necessary corrections. 

Your cooperation and prompt attention are legally required. 

Sincerely, XXXX XXXX

Consumer complaint narrative:
Complaint to the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau ( CFPB ) Date : XX/XX/year> Subject : Complaint Against XXXX XXXX XXXX for Non-Response to Rescission of Signature To Whom It May Concern, I am filing this formal complaint against XXXX XXXX XXXX regarding their failure to respond to my rescission of signature notice within the legally required timeframe under the Truth in Lending Act ( TILA ) and associated federal regulations. 

Background Information XXXX. Rescission of Signature Submission : XXXX OF XXXX  a Rescission of Signature to XXXX XXXX XXXX regarding a contract associated with my account [ Account Number or Reference ]. This rescission was tendered under my rights outlined in the Truth in Lending Act ( 15 U.S.C. 1635 ) and Uniform Commercial Code ( UCC 2-207, 3-603, and 3-306 ) due to the discovery of itemizations and contractual irregularities. 


XXXX. XXXX Non-Response Period : Under federal law, XXXX XXXX XXXX was required to respond to my rescission within XXXX calendar days of receipt, either acknowledging the rescission or providing a written explanation rejecting the rescission along with supporting legal justification. To date, no response has been received. 



Complaint Details 1. Failure to Respond : XXXX XXXX XXXX has failed to provide any acknowledgment, acceptance, or rejection of my rescission of signature within the required timeframe. This constitutes a violation of the Truth in Lending Act and potentially other federal regulations governing consumer credit transactions. 


XXXX. Request for Notice of Non-Response : As part of this complaint, I am providing a Notice of Non-Response to XXXX XXXX XXXX, effectively declaring the contract void and unenforceable unless XXXX XXXX XXXX can provide evidence of their response to my rescission of signature within the legally required timeframe. 


XXXX. Request for Documentation : I formally request that XXXX XXXX XXXX provide written documentation detailing : Their response to my rescission of signature, if any. 

The specific legal basis, statutes, or terms that justify their response ( or lack thereof ). 




Resolution Requested I am seeking the following resolutions through this complaint : XXXX. A full and detailed response from XXXX XXXX XXXX regarding their failure to address my rescission of signature within 20 days. 


XXXX. A declaration that the contract is void and unenforceable due to their non-response, in accordance with applicable federal laws. 


XXXX. Compensation for any damages or adverse actions resulting from their failure to comply with the statutory requirements of the Truth in Lending Act. 



Supporting Documentation I have included the following documents with this complaint : A copy of the original rescission of signature letter submitted to XXXX XXXX XXXX. 

Proof of delivery showing the date XXXX XXXX XXXX received the rescission. 

Copies of any related correspondence or communications with XXXX XXXX XXXX. 


Conclusion This complaint is submitted in good faith and with the expectation that the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau will investigate this matter and ensure that XXXX XXXX XXXX complies with federal law. I respectfully request timely acknowledgment of this complaint and a response outlining the next steps in this matter.

Product: Credit reporting or other personal consumer reports
Consumer complaint narrative:
I am writing to formally request the deletion of an unverifiable account from my credit report under the provisions of the Fair Credit Reporting Act ( FCRA ), 15 U.S.C. 1681 et seq. Specifically, this pertains to the account identified as a {$720.00} charge-off with XXXXXXXX XXXX XXXX XXXX 
After disputing this account with XXXX, their investigation was completed on XX/XX/year>. Following the investigation, XXXX deleted this account from my credit report, as the information could not be verified. If XXXX has removed the account due to its unverifiability, I urge you to take similar action and remove this account from my credit report promptly. 
Under the FCRA, all credit reporting agencies are required to ensure that the information on consumer reports is accurate, complete, and verifiable. Specifically : Section 611 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ) of the FCRA mandates that credit reporting agencies conduct a reasonable investigation of disputed information.

If the disputed information can not be verified as accurate, Section 611 ( a ) ( 5 ) ( A ) requires the
credit reporting agency to delete it from the consumers credit file.

Furthermore, under Section 623 ( a ) ( 1 ) ( A ), furnishers of information must not provide information that they know or have reasonable cause to believe is inaccurate. 
Since XXXX has deemed this account unverifiable and deleted it, I expect the same resolution from your agency. If this unverifiable debt is not removed within 30 days from the receipt of this letter, I reserve the right to pursue further legal action under the FCRA. 
Failure to comply with FCRA requirements may subject your organization to statutory damages, actual damages, court costs, and reasonable attorney fees under Section 616 and Section 617 of the FCRA. Additionally, if willful noncompliance is found, I may be entitled to punitive damages. 
To ensure a clear record of this request, I have attached the relevant documentation, including confirmation from XXXX regarding the deletion of the account. 
Please confirm in writing that this account has been deleted from my credit report or provide a detailed explanation of your investigation findings. I expect a response within the time frame outlined by the FCRA. 
Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter. 
Sincerely, XXXX XXXX XXXX Enclosures : 1. Copy of confirmation from XXXX regarding account deletion 2. Copy of my credit report showing the disputed account ( if applicable ) 3. Any additional supporting documentation
